On 02 Apr 2007 20:53:36 -0700, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
> Adrian Parker wrote:
>  >
>  >
>  > Hello,
>  >
>  > I have observed that both setup() and the constructor for the test class are
>  > called once for each test method. I have put an example below. Why is the
>  > constructor, and not just setup(), called many times? Shouldn't it be that
>  > only setup is called once for each test? I've used both ant and eclipse to
>  > run the test case. I'm a little fuzzy on how this is even possible.
>
>  Although JUnit invokes each test it in its own instance of TestCase, it
>  reserves the right to pool instances if it wanted to. NUnit, for
>  example, pools instances of the test case class, but respects the
>  contract for, in its case, the [SetUp] and [TearDown] labels.
>
>  The goal of running each test in its own instance is test isolation. If
>  the tests are separate objects, there's no chance of an uninitialized
>  field corrupting a future test.

What is the distinction between setup() and the constructor?  They
both seem to provide the same functionality (they are both called anew
before every test method)?



Adrian
